text:
Q: Unable to find method ''java.lang.String com.squareup.javapoet.ClassName.canonicalName()'' A:

You forgot to declare the KSP and the Hilt plugin in the project-level gradle file. It should look like this (note the last two lines):

plugins {
    alias(libs.plugins.android.application) apply false
    alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.android) apply false
    alias(libs.plugins.kotlin.compose) apply false
    alias(libs.plugins.ksp) apply false
    alias(libs.plugins.hilt.plugin) apply false
}

Furthermore, you mix Hilt artifacts of different versions (2.57.1 and 2.57.2). Although not responsible for the problem at hand this can easily lead to other errors. Since you already use a version catalog you should move the dependencies there as well and use the same version hiltver that you already use for the plugin.

Q: Read all tags from Allen-Bradley PLC A:

You found it yourself in the comments, wrong slot number.

192.168.1.5/1 means slot 1. Your PLC is in slot 0, so it should be:

with LogixDriver('192.168.1.5/0') as plc:

The connection "worked" because something responded at that IP, but slot 1 either has a different module or nothing, hence zero tags. Slot 0 is where the CPU typically lives in a ControlLogix chassis.

Q: PNG of exam ID is clearly visible but not correctly recognized A:

This problem occurred as an interaction of two aspects:

  • The scanned PNG is rotated to the right and somewhat distorted (so that even after rotation to the left not everything is completely upright).

  • The exam ID label ("Class: OSWALD") is rather long.

The code in nops_scan() was able to deal with both issues separately. But in combination the upper border of the exam ID box was not recognized correctly, leading to traces of the text not being properly shaved

The bug was fixed in version 2.4-3 of the package. At the time of writing this is only available on R-Forge and can be installed from there. But it will also be released to CRAN soon.

Q: How to fix and parse dates based on unpatterened input formats A:

With the proviso, from comments, that the whole column is input in chronological order, and only under this condition, using base functions:

dates <- c("2022-7-9", "2022-9-12", "9-14-2022", "9-25-2022", "26-9-2022", "1-10-2022", "6-10-2022", "2022-10-8", "2022-12-10")
#indices
ymd_idx <- which(as.numeric(as.Date(dates, format = '%Y-%m-%d')) > 0)
[1] 1 2 8 9
ydm_idx <- which(as.numeric(as.Date(dates, format = '%Y-%d-%m')) > 0)
[1] 1 2 8 9
# Dang, which are they? 
all(as.numeric(as.Date(dates[ymd_idx], format = '%Y-%m-%d')) == cummax(as.numeric(as.Date(dates[ymd_idx], format = '%Y-%m-%d'))))
[1] TRUE
all(as.numeric(as.Date(dates[ydm_idx], format = '%Y-%d-%m')) == cummax(as.numeric(as.Date(dates[ydm_idx], format = '%Y-%d-%m'))))
[1] FALSE
# they're %Y-%m-%d
# dmy index
dmy_idx <- which(is.na(as.numeric(as.Date(dates, format = '%d-%m-%Y'))) == FALSE)
[1] 5 6 7
# Leaving
mdy_idx <- setdiff(1:length(dates), union(ymd_idx, dmy_idx))
[1] 3 4
as.numeric(as.Date(dates[mdy_idx], format = '%m-%d-%Y'))
[1] 19249 19260

Well, kludgy in it's own way. The all( test from monotonically increasing
